EACC201EABF84881827653543095B92A.description: reflects on, analyzes, and assesses strategies used while learning Nakaw?.

739EF854A6294134A0B911E80D8BB02D.description: determines personal inquiry and learning goals; and,

3454DBF0E8A04F78BF35132AEF5633F8.description: reflects on new knowledge of Nakaw? and its value to self and the wider community;

E72AF89993BE456AAAC2B67BD6D5D3F5.description: determines personal inquiry and research strengths and language goals;

4F832684473E4D548F262D7AEDEA9ACD.description: reviews, refines, through reflection, feedback and self-assessment;

DF5A0185603C4BC2BC597342AA35AD19.description: reflects on attainment of personal goals for effective language learning and use;

E91EAB10BEA34D79A121F74DCFEBA138.description: assesses own and others' work for clarity, correctness and impact;

1ED0D70C18A24398BE7EAC450B42C845.description: Assess personal strengths and needs within the development of their own language learning as they relate to family, community and land and set goals for future improvement.

454DEF5AB6BA494ABDDD40DED2C03D48.description: uses criteria and rubrics to evaluate presentations including the purpose, delivery, content, visual aids, body language, and facial expressions.

2C7FFEEAC4284CBF976A9F4E71FA25D0.description: evaluates and modifies own roles in group interactions; and,

6B3C6ED22BB04B57AC6E5E900C0F5B7D.description: recognizes speaking, listening, viewing and representing are useful tools for clarifying thinking, communicating and learning;

0323106DFCAD46C8809B47C6F94289A8.description: reflects on factors that influence identity through the use of the Nakaw? language;

6573C4D5A1574FBAB8D1DC575B3CCD46.description: Assess personal strengths and needs within the development of their own language skill, and set goals for future improvement.

142BCD5E91A740FFA503C3BB0E198B73.description: discusses options using words for possibility, comparison, contrast and cause; e.g., compare and contrast artwork done by Saskatchewan artists, or discuss the pros and cons of living in the city.

222F7D03741C45D69F0DCC00882B364A.description: gives a set of instructions with appropriate sequence, rules, conditions and imperatives, such as how to make jam using blueberries or raspberries, or how to clean and tan a moose hide; and,

07282B05762144A18A9FDC982EE4A46A.description: describes or narrates an experience, event or situation with supporting detail; e.g., life on the trap line, prepare wild game, setting a fishnet, or educational experiences;

E3A0E1E5AFEA466ABC88E74BEE2A7343.description: explores effective forms for recording and presenting and uses for research findings, such as CD-ROMs, video archives, children's literature;

A4BA5BC1E380428297D722579DBF21BC.description: perform language functions that allow them to produce communication.

9BFDF687E1BA4E088D57B4B074124985.description: approaches cultural resource people with appropriate protocol for collecting information;

DBDD7532A559466C8A231B29A031B180.description: identifies possible sources of information, resource people, written resources and media resources;

26D6935BB7254F74AF44E798A97C17B6.description: forms possible research or inquiry questions;

973AEB758CCF43358E17141DEBCC1486.description: identifies and inquires a need or purpose for collecting cultural information in consultation with Elders;

99D1F779A1B2448885EACFD703A0895E.description: perform language functions that allow them to produce research.

BB943E2B88F748FCA5B600F017DE8819.description: relates personally to a character or situation in moral stories.

F6DC83B4B9974EA8BB966F10F51E3238.description: demonstrates recognition of language techniques used for effectiveness of presentation such as voice, or the use of metaphors; and,

DBA27FA6B84F445FAAFDD54BF882E0DE.description: searches for meaning in the unspoken discourse, such as ellipses, symbols, metaphors;

DC50F66AAB1D412DA03BA89A504E2809.description: after hearing/viewing/reading discourse: demonstrates by outlining, summarizing, paraphrasing and answering questions, comprehension of main idea and details;

AA67F6033A1F48999D9FC1AE7B50D166.description: engages in previewing or hearing activities that orient to the discourse, such as providing background knowledge, recalling what is already known;

A8751DD581AF471A8AFDD0F96B113222.description: perform language functions that allow them to interpret communications.

9A89DED226A54579BDE8E00BC572C335.description: demonstrates and uses language families and dialectssystematic sound differences and reasons for differences in vocabulary.

D7A66AB92D4345B898EC563FB8985E1A.description: uses language and other protocols governing relationships between and among people during ceremonies and special events; and,

AE8AB1DA7BE8413EAC23EF5E622363B9.description: uses inclusive language to welcome guests into the home, school or community;

1770A2BE6B3D4F1697B80F5EC40DBF12.description: perform language functions that allow them to socialize and celebrate.

223F8EF6384D474586308BE1488C5857.description: asks questions, asks for repetition to clarify understanding.

AB77D5DEF2FC460AB92168508DF9D084.description: seeks information to help formulate personal understanding; and,

7CBF484BD6EC4A26B2EEC61AB8E480A4.description: develops ways of organizing and clarifying personal thinking and ideas;

E7797ECE371E4DC99E500CF41B77B156.description: uses questions to understand new ideas;

DACC5294C60D4258BD52F467FB315342.description: uses Nakaw? to persuade or convince;

5CEBC3A15B1A4C00AFB5B63FC63EE4BB.description: follows simple instructions for doing something (e.g., brush teeth, wash face, write on the board);

A3757C7F00D24207BD124019E8C65E77.description: discusses plans (e.g., going to the library, going for coffee, meeting for volleyball);

3FCA3081FF88441C860B8ACC3B70339C.description: perform language functions that allow the learner to receive and give information.

4E817F37AAE04193A32E1A6CD4FDAF16.description: uses a variety of patterns in their own texts.

1A19627B899F4C50A0F18EF4C7E4171A.description: uses a variety of conventions to structure texts (e.g., titles, poetry, and riddles/ jokes); and,

8682BBE34E094EC28ADF69CA7A7EDA1A.description: uses a variety of short oral texts on unfamiliar topics in guided situations;

C31B0C98AB9B45FF84C4DC56F38506C5.description: uses simple linking devices, such as "k?spin-if" and "sigwa therefore," appropriately in spontaneous speech to create a sense of flow and coherency;

04CFDAEC797241E8BE2125EB7C5A58CB.description: expresses some logical relations in discourse;

D7FDA2B24C344EBA8EFCE06E7D1D4801.description: conveys an idea in discourse with a logical sequence of events and with simple but effective detail;

07A153C378C049C1B8DAC0F26C1E0B18.description: communicate meaningfully with coherency (coherency relates to the connectedness of information, thoughts, and ideas with discourse).

7D5B0B1C2E084CE3B4679E8F500CEA8F.description: produces basic phrases, short sentences, and questions using learned vocabulary and simple language structures.

A923D650CB73493CB4AD871CBC3050DB.description: participates in a simple conversation with a Nakaw? speaker using repetition and explanation; and,

EE5BA2F4FEDF4D408C6B84A756F2A516.description: manages simple, routine interactions with ease and asks for clarification when necessary;

D20955F9526F4E5EB64AAB7A1CA69D9E.description: produces speech at a normal or slower than normal rate that requires some repetition to be understood by a first language speaker;

84B0E0A086D141078795C4445961C733.description: communicate meaningfully with proficiency (proficiency is the ability of an individual to speak or perform in an acquired language).

7D6062CB48CC474D9F77AA5FE64B5CE6.description: produces a variety of short, simple oral texts in guided and unguided situations.

14FD4A852DBB44E3B8F68D636B2E4158.description: uses a wider range of common verbal affixes with relative accuracy; and,

F9948F08911C46AFA61088976875C48B.description: produces sentences containing a subordinate clause;

A96EE98049FA438B806FED640713EE9C.description: uses specific vocabulary associated with a range of common topics;

1ACD3C44B0BA4683B5A63F9803B5F666.description: produces sounds of language that are difficult for the student learning an additional language, with enough clarity to prevent misunderstandings of commo words;

83202CE044BF43399DC307BCD27DCF8C.description: communicate meaningfully with accuracy (accuracy primarily the syntactical and semantical conventions of a language)

D3C52B22D2FF4809A8ABB2FEC63DDA14.description: identifies and develops own strengths related to Nakaw? language and culture.

CB5F0BB8AC93417FBDF0610CEF053598.description: identifies language and cultural role models (who they are and what makes them unique); and,

8CDA3E2F41674C019BFE33A0F608A87C.description: works with language mentors (e.g., parents, friends, peers, Elders) to monitor and improve own learning;

E9FB53C8AA5642469C8CC69B717C0577.description: identifies effective mental techniques to improve learning Nakaw?;

77226CD9FD1045E088579CE166F2E155.description: demonstrates willingness to take risks and to try unfamiliar tasks and approaches;

DAFBFC5673E6488D85A6C1C58360847D.description: asks for clarification or repetition to aid understanding;

0AF3023A5FF246A09F89B999B113DBAF.description: repeats and uses new words and expressions occurring in conversation with others;

F39477638CBC4236A577B0CFE333F64C.description: develops criteria for assessing own work;

20CD25639F3D46B29752714646B0E983.description: identifies problems that may hinder successful completion of a task and seek solutions;

D5C5F5582EF643DA88705B4D09249AB6.description: demonstrates how strategies may assist with texts containing unknown elements;

FDE4CAC09FA7402B85A09A67952BF708.description: demonstrates awareness of learning through direct exposure to Nakaw? by asking questions when someone is speaking.;

53059672FC15461AA8BC51F15EC972F8.description: uses key content words or context clues to follow an extended text;

8BA7307174CE4849817E8B65C398AE45.description: places new words or expressions in a context to make them easier to remember;

D0CD98B741A34B639581F716CB66F678.description: uses graphic representations (e.g., word maps, mind maps, diagrams, charts) to make information easier to understand and to remember;

1B2BDC0DE02245F3A1B5DB3D399F6C1B.description: identifies and justifies the evidence on which inferences are based;

B8142652402C4906BD0D0B8DDF4C5D5F.description: makes personal notes when hearing useful language;

5E7036A8DFCF4D868DB5529485F7C955.description: volunteers initiating or ending a conversation;

0AAC3B54E56145B9971F291F70219E9F.description: seeks opportunities to use or hear the language;

A6102105EBD04FD5A50A95E137BB8C89.description: uses reference materials and speakers to help in clarifying a message;

C17FC96B82C3448AB7B5E500B8CBEF52.description: uses grammatical knowledge to correct errors or to improve their language;

154E807D87C343B7880F7DEE5E32C4B1.description: distinguishes relevant information from irrelevant information when trying to get the gist of a speech or difficult conversation;

DDD95EEF9E05460ABDB45D424F4247CC.description: decides in advance what to listen for;

54F925620C844500B6331AE113AD84C1.description: develop and use various strategies to enhance the meaning of learning and communication.

515D31BA2D3047CAB455EF597F9A4B3F.description: presents an oral narrative or other creative text and accompanies it with a visual, kinaesthetic or oral presentation that adds to its effectiveness for a particular audience, such as a poem put to music, script or dialogue acted out, or gives instructions on how to do a particular task.

036998740D04438EADBD8CAECFFC19D4.description: writes a factual report based on inquiry and presents information accompanying the written report with a visual, oral or kinaesthetic presentation that adds to its effectiveness for a particular audience; and,

B3E8C014CEDD460B96246E2724EF07CA.description: writes notes and presents orally to capture basic information from inquiry or from a personal or electronic source, such as a short interview, weather report or short film;

C5C66D11F757414089950149A2E1DFD5.description: shares personal reflections created, such as a speech and as written text, in response to personal experiences or Nakaw? worldviews;

8B3A7B3D97B34F0A86502CB08A4722DF.description: various mediums of expression, such as dance, puppetry, art, or drama;

87786D5B73514C34A7A6C93B89CA76FF.description: retells parts of oral narratives orally and in written form, and combines with;

0177A8B3107D4642BBF65453D3C9779C.description: communicates thoughts, ideas, feelings for specific purposes and audiences through a variety of verbal and visual media in guided situations;

03976ED1D9894FAAAF8DA0B1B395D1BB.description: produces text on familiar topics, providing detail to support main point, in guided situations;

685E58A275BE4538B59E7156FF279132.description: produce language that is understandable to others.

922589061749416D933A9825CEA96BCB.description: reads and interprets a descriptive passage of text or a detailed set of instructions for a process, supported with occasional informative illustrations.

53B81B12C7F4490EBF300F88FB4855B8.description: reads and interprets simple excerpts from stories from the oral tradition; stories should be supported with occasional informative illustrations, photos, or other visual representations; and,

AB9457133AE14E83BD724C5CF6852B21.description: listens to and interprets some of the proceedings of community meetings regarding topics relevant to cultural areas of study, such as meetings with Elders, band council meetings, school committee meetings;

4930C30F2DA542AA97C2AE18227D6DA0.description: interprets and responds to contemporary Nakaw? reflections expressed in a variety of mediums, such as documentaries on a topic of choice, or modern Nakaw? art, dance, drama, and music;

AF7E959C7C1143829E1C0F994D207D8B.description: interprets and responds to traditional narratives of the people relating to areas of Nakaw? world-views: histories, moral stories, songs, informational texts and entertaining stories, from electronic or print mediums;

B0F077937F7B4176936337EAEE4FE066.description: understand and interpret the Nakaw? language as a connected set of ideas expressed in sentences.

BDD9FB93B6594DC3819636CC6E31F68C.description: interacts with Elders or cultural resource people while inquiring about the Nakaw? world-view to learn about the history, past practices and past customs.

C803BD8D4547442DB6AF7A61FEC67210.description: interacts with members of the community in acts of service to the community, such as helping with the preparation of activities, programming for community radio, television or print media; and,

4E0D6439469445FD8D18E445CB3775DB.description: interacts with members of the community while participating in community events, such as winter festival, language festival, dance competitions or music festivals;

CD76B6F4227F469199CF31985FD9C6E3.description: interacts with members of the community and Elders while participating in culture camps;

163A99DFA0AE429C85EF21FCE4543AA6.description: interacts with Elders or cultural resource people to learn cultural skills in the learners natural surroundings;

171450943F784EDEB2A391E766DF6190.description: listens and responds to a variety of extended text forms in a variety of media (e.g., short stories, films, plays, etc.);

84E4DBD4DB8C4C1AB068762366DA90B2.description: identifies the main point and supporting details of lengthy texts on topics of interest in guided situations;

6111B0677F834036B0BE597F0663C77B.description: identifies the purpose of texts (e.g., to describe, retell, persuade, entertain and instruct);

DF02549BE3E942939AD2428E297CBC3A.description: listens and responds to short texts on topics of interest in guided or unguided situations;

0A2C883718ED4708A9633E5F1EE54F3F.description: view, interact with, and experience the natural and constructed environments of the community.
